subSections.title: Etymology
subSections.text:
Unclear. Possibly an areal word ({{zh-ref|Schuessler, 2007}}). Compare {{cog|mro|tr=rak|t=eldest brother}} and Kukish {{m|und||prak|t=eldest brother}} ({{zh-ref|Löffler, 1966}}), as well as {{cog|lhu|phâ||god; lord}} < {{cog|th|พระ}} < {{cog|mkh-okm|bra}} or {{cog|mkh-okm-A|braḥ}}, {{m|mkh-okm|braḥh}}, {{m|mkh-okm|brah||[[distinguished]]; [[divine]]; [[excellent]]; [[holy]]; [[sacred]]; [[superior]]; etc.}} (see {{cog|km|ព្រះ}} for more).

Possibly related to {{inh|zh|sit-pro|*bʷaŋ ~ *pʷaŋ||(paternal) uncle; elder brother}}, in turn possibly related to {{och-l|兄|elder brother}} ({{zh-ref|Benedict, 1972}}).

Alternatively, from {{och-l|白|white}}; compare {{och-l|皤|white}}, which underwent parallel semantic shift to "white-haired", though this is possibly folk etymology ({{zh-ref|Schuessler, 2007}}).

Pronunciation 2 is the exoactive/transitive of pronunciation 1 ([[ibid.]]).

|mn-t=bêh4
|mc=y
|oc=y

}}

subSections.title: Definitions
Usage notes
subSections.text: In Old Chinese, sons of a same father are referred to in order as {{zh-l|伯|first}}, {{zh-l|仲|second}}, {{zh-l|叔|third}} and {{zh-l|季 |fourth}}. The usage of {{zh-l|*仲}} and {{zh-l|*季}} was later eliminated but {{zh-l|*伯}} and {{zh-l|*叔}} remained in use when referring to one's father's elder and younger brothers and male cousins. Moreover, {{lang|zh|伯仲叔季}} were commonly used in personal names in the past, and this is still occasionally seen nowadays.

* [[伯母]] ([[백모]], ''baek-mo'') father's elder brother's wife
